data.title: Best Colleges And Universities In New Jersey 2023
data.meta_description: The east coast is full of internship and business opportunities, as well as educational options, but if you’re looking for excitement and the hustle and
data.text:
The east coast is full of internship and business opportunities, as well as educational options, but if you’re looking for excitement and the hustle and bustle of an urban education, New Jersey would be an excellent option for you. With big cities like Philadelphia and New York come big opportunities.

The New Jersey State Department of Education offers tuition aid that can help you attend one of its many colleges and universities. The Tuition Aid Grant (TAG) and Part-Time Tuition Aid Grant are available to attendees of all New Jersey colleges and universities. At certain colleges, the state even administers the Educational Opportunity Fund.

Related Programs That Might Interest You

Learn about start dates, transferring credits, availability of financial aid, and more by contacting the universities below.

Community College students are eligible for the state’s Opportunity Grant. Women and minority groups, specifically, are eligible for the Governor’s Industry Vocations Scholarship. More information about these programs can be found at https://www.state.nj.us/nj/education/aid/.

Besides all the educational opportunities and assistance programs, New Jersey is full of enjoyable places to visit. With nearly 130 miles of coastline, inland mountains, and open access to all that New York City has to offer, this state has everything an aspiring young student could want, and more.

Ranking Methodology

The Best Colleges in New Jersey ranking is based on four main data points in four categories:

Schools are ranked based on four data points in four categories:

Affordability (net price)

Student Satisfaction (retention rate)

Academic Quality (4-year graduation rate)

Salary After Attending (the median earnings of former students who received federal financial aid, 10 years after entering the school)

All data for this ranking was gathered from the National Center for Education Statistics and College Scorecard.

In the case of a tie in scoring, the average net price was the determining factor for which school received the higher rank–the lower the net price, the higher the ranking.

Best Accredited Colleges and Universities in New Jersey 2023

1. Princeton University

Score: 100.0

Average Net Price: $9,836

Retention Rate: 91%

Graduation Rate: 97%

Salary After Attending: $95,689

The prestigious private institution that is Princeton University can be found in Princeton, New Jersey. It is a relatively modest educational establishment with a total undergraduate enrollment of 5,321 students. Given that just 6% of applicants are accepted each year, the admissions process is highly difficult. The fields of economics, computer science, and public policy analysis are among the most popular majors. U.S. News and World Report ranked Princeton University #1 among national universities, #3 in best undergraduate teaching, and #30 in most innovative schools. The faculty at Princeton is widely recognized as world-class experts in their respective fields, as well as remarkable educators and devoted instructors.

2. New Jersey Institute of Technology

Score: 95.3

Average Net Price: $18,582

Retention Rate: 89%

Graduation Rate: 79%

Salary After Attending: $80,043

The New Jersey Institute of Technology comes in at #97 among National Universities and sits at #118 among Best Value Schools. A few of the most popular majors include architecture, biology, and engineering. With an acceptance rate of just 69%, an applicant's GPA is one of the essential factors of acceptance, alongside letters of recommendation. Plenty of NJIT classes host less than 20 students at a time, which makes class lectures both more engaging and personal. NJIT's "Major & Degree Finder" page states that they offer "122-degree programs through six professional schools and colleges." NJIT offers more than 46 online programs--14 online master's degree programs and 21 graduate certificate programs.

3. Rutgers University-Newark

Score: 94.8

Average Net Price: $15,996

Retention Rate: 85%

Graduation Rate: 71%

Salary After Attending: $65,661

Rutgers' additional campus is located in Newark and ranks at #115 among National Universities, unlike its New Brunswick counterpart. Nonetheless, Newark is still an excellent option. Though undergraduate enrollment and campus size are also significantly less than in Rutgers' other locations, the quality of education is the same. Some popular degrees include accounting, finance, and criminal justice. Graduate students attend either the School of Law, Business School, or the School of Criminal Justice--which is also highly ranked. One of the most notable aspects of this Rutgers campus is its remarkable alumni list, including several Federal Bureau of Investigation employees and even a former U.S. Secretary of Energy. This campus maintains over 100 different clubs and organizations despite its small size.

Image Source

4. Rutgers University-Camden

Score: 93.5

Average Net Price: $16,369

Retention Rate: 85%

Graduation Rate: 68%

Salary After Attending: $65,661

This Rutgers campus is quite similar to its Newark counterpart, but it is slightly larger and ranks #127 among National Universities. Some popular degrees include registered nursing, accounting, and criminal justice. With an acceptance rate of 79%, earning a high SAT or ACT score can boost your admission chances. Letters of recommendation are not essential, so focusing on your grades and test scores is more likely to increase your chance of acceptance. It's important to note that almost half the courses on this campus comprise less than 20 students at a time, and the average student-to-faculty ratio is 15-to- 1. This ratio is slightly less than the previous colleges mentioned. The school also offers a few dual degree programs that will undoubtedly assist in your post-college success.

5. Rutgers University-New Brunswick

Score: 93.0

Average Net Price: $23,035

Retention Rate: 93%

Graduation Rate: 81%

Salary After Attending: $65,661

Rutgers University ranks #55 among all National Universities, topping the list for Best Colleges in New Jersey. The university offers a wide array of degree options and sports to be involved in. Campus sports teams have even won a few championships in the past. Rutgers sits at #27 among Best Colleges for Veterans, so if you're a service member, it's definitely worth looking into. The only notable downside is that the acceptance rate was reported only at 68% in 2023, but if you have been a great student thus far that may not be a concern.

Image Source

6. Stevens Institute of Technology

Score: 92.5

Average Net Price: $37,211

Retention Rate: 94%

Graduation Rate: 86%

Salary After Attending: $98,159

Stevens Institute of Technology boasts more than a few remarkable features and with its relatively small campus size it's an excellent option for those looking for more personalized education. Even though this college ranks at #83 among National Universities it may seem daunting to attend an Institute of Technology especially since this campus was notably a male-only school until the early 1970s. Enhanced networking opportunities arise from the advantage of smaller class sizes, proving particularly advantageous for students pursuing highly sought-after fields like business management or engineering. Opting to reside on campus can be an optimal choice, as the guarantee of four-year housing and a campus population where over half of the students reside present appealing benefits. Now, females generally make up about 30% of those enrolled so this campus is a comfortable place for anyone to receive a top-of-the-line education regardless of gender.

Image Source

7. The College of New Jersey

Score: 91.0

Average Net Price: $28,245

Retention Rate: 93%

Graduation Rate: 85%

Salary After Attending: $65,481

The College of New Jersey ranks #5 among Regional Universities North. Though it maintains an undergraduate enrollment of just under 7,000 students, the school features an impressive 289-acre campus. The school offers over 50 programs across its various schools of study, as well as over 150 different student organizations. This campus offers quite a few unique options for aspiring artists and other creatives. The school has two separate theaters, a music hall, an art gallery, and even a television and radio station hosted by students.

Image Source

8. Ramapo College of New Jersey

Score: 90.3

Average Net Price: $21,707

Retention Rate: 85%

Graduation Rate: 73%

Salary After Attending: $60,019

Ramapo College of New Jersey makes an impressive stand on our list, coming in at #28 among Regional Universities North. Undergraduate enrollment averages around 5,000, and the expansive campus sits on nearly 300 acres. Ramapo awards 40 different degrees, maintains over 100 student organizations, and boasts 25 fraternities and sororities for students to choose from. The school also affords a variety of creative outlets for students, such as the school newspaper or the literary magazine, both of which are student-run. Ramapo typically allows students to play intramural sports, but everyone is free to try out for any of the school's varsity sports teams. If you're big into sports, know that Ramapo competes in the NCAA Division III. The school also places #13 among Best Colleges for Veterans and #16 for Best Undergraduate Teaching.

Image Source

9. Montclair State University

Score: 89.3

Average Net Price: $17,381

Retention Rate: 81%

Graduation Rate: 71%

Salary After Attending: $54,289

Montclair ranks #182 among National Universities, boasting a large campus, low tuition, and more than 300 different academic programs at all levels. The school's career-planning services are designed to help students find internships, job opportunities, and networking experiences. More than 200 clubs are available, as well as Greek life and athletic teams at both the intramural and varsity level. Montclair's campus is only 12 miles away from New York City, so students have open access to a plethora of urban adventures, not to mention internships, job opportunities, and creative outlets close to the big city. A few of the school's most actively-pursued majors include visual and performing arts, social and human sciences, and various other business degrees.

10. Stockton University

Score: 87.8

Average Net Price: $21,404

Retention Rate: 84%

Graduation Rate: 76%

Salary After Attending: $51,729

Stockton University ranks #182 among National Universities and maintains ten undergraduate academic departments. The school's natural sciences, mathematics, arts, and humanities programs are the most widely known. Stockton allows students to begin their research projects early on, aiding them in their education process and upping their chances of receiving fellowships. Stockton accepts 85% of undergraduate applicants, and at 84%, the freshmen retention rate is quite high. The school maintains a 2,000 acre-campus to accommodate its enrollment of over 8,300 undergraduates. With such low tuition rates, this school maintains one of the best balances between the price and quality of any college out there.

Image Source

11. Rowan University

Score: 86.8

Average Net Price: $27,158

Retention Rate: 84%

Graduation Rate: 75%

Salary After Attending: $55,410

Rowan has evolved as an environmental research institution, having received over 13 green initiative awards. There are plenty of undergraduate and graduate degree options to choose from, but the school is most widely known for its S.T.E.M. majors. Rowan accepts 84% of applicants, and admissions are based on applicants' G.P.A. and recommendation letters. The freshman retention rate is high, and classes typically have fewer students. Rowan ranks #194 among National Universities. Overall, the cost and quality are a perfect balance.

12. Seton Hall University

Score: 86.8

Average Net Price: $32,634

Retention Rate: 83%

Graduation Rate: 70%

Salary After Attending: $68,441

Seton Hall is a small private school that sits at #137 among National Universities. The majority-led Catholic school is located only about 15 miles from New York City, so local adventures are just a train ride away. Seton Hall students can choose from over 60 different majors or pursue one of the school's top-of-the-line graduate programs within one of the schools of Business, Education, or Law. The university maintains over 100 student organizations, Greek Life groups, and sports teams. Seton Hall's most popular majors include biological sciences, marketing, and nursing. Half of the classes have less than 20 students at a time, and the student-to-faculty ratio is only 15 to 1. Most Seton Hall graduates typically stay in the New Jersey and New York area to pursue the city's plentiful professional opportunities.

13. Monmouth University

Score: 86.3

Average Net Price: $29,877

Retention Rate: 81%

Graduation Rate: 73%

Salary After Attending: $59,513

Today, the school enrolls a relatively small number of undergraduates but maintains an impressive campus on 168 acres of eastern Long Branch, New Jersey. A few of the most popular majors include business and management, health professions, communications, and more. Monmouth offers unique academic opportunities such as senior capstone seminars, writing classes, creative projects, and a plethora of other memorable first-year student experiences.

14. Drew University

Score: 86.0

Average Net Price: $25,776

Retention Rate: 86%

Graduation Rate: 61%

Salary After Attending: $57,185

Since its founding in 1867, Drew University has been committed to the pursuit of bettering its students and its community through education. The school's most popular degree options include both the social and biological sciences, and visual and performing arts. Overall, Drew ranks #111 among National Liberal Arts Colleges. Due to its small campus, undergraduate enrollment is typically less than 2,000 annually. Drew even enables students to experience a "Wall Street Semester," among a few other NYC-based career-building opportunities.

15. Fairleigh Dickinson University-Metropolitan Campus

Score: 84.8

Average Net Price: $12,069

Retention Rate: 74%

Graduation Rate: 50%

Salary After Attending: $55,994

The Metropolitan Campus of Fairleigh Dickinson University has been serving its community through education and service since its founding in 1942. The various sports, large residence halls, and the recently constructed fitness center (to promote students' health and well-being) all contribute to a vibrant campus atmosphere. FDU-Metropolitan residence halls allow for unique living options. For example, there are specific halls for students who require quiet studying, honors students, and even individuals who prioritize physical exercise and prefer to have access to an on-site gym. All in all, Fairleigh Dickinson at the Metropolitan is one of the most student-friendly campuses on this list. It is a school that prioritizes its students' needs to better prepare them for successful futures and careers.

16. Saint Peter's University

Score: 84.8

Average Net Price: $12,470

Retention Rate: 78%

Graduation Rate: 55%

Salary After Attending: $51,027

Saint Peter's University is a private, Roman Catholic institution that ranks #58 among Regional Universities in North. The school's programs include business, biomedical sciences, and protective services. Of all freshmen, 78% remain at the school for the years required to earn their degree, which is a relatively high statistic for any college to claim. Saint Peter's teams up with other universities, such as Rutgers University, to combine various degree programs. The institution is also G.I. Bill certified and participates in the Yellow Ribbon Program, which can be an essential factor for some students. With a 93% acceptance rate, grades, test scores, and letters of recommendation are all important factors for gaining acceptance.

Image Source

17. Felician University

Score: 84.3

Average Net Price: $16,984

Retention Rate: 79%

Graduation Rate: 51%

Salary After Attending: $54,650

Felician University is a private, suburban institution that has been dedicated to furthering individualized education since its founding in 1942. Today, the school typically enrolls around 2,000 students or less with only 27 acres to the university. Felician offers unique combined-degree programs, the most popular of which include health professions, business, and biology-related sciences. Almost 70% of classes host less than 20 students, so networking and establishing contacts is a given. Felician accepts 92% of applicants, and the admissions team looks at students' GPAs and test scores as major deciding factors. The typical A.C.T. score for Felician is between 15 and 22, and the application fee, tuition, and fees are relatively low.

18. William Paterson University of New Jersey

Score: 84.3

Average Net Price: $18,498

Retention Rate: 78%

Graduation Rate: 61%

Salary After Attending: $51,506

The William Peterson University of New Jersey has been committed to providing education and bolstering students' futures since its founding in 1855. Today, the school ranks #75 among Regional Universities in North. Enrollment and campus size are relatively average, but tuition rates are quite low, even for out-of-state applicants. Over half of WPU's classes comprise less than 20 students each, meaning each student receives the most individualized education possible. A few of the most popular majors include business, psychology, communication, protective services, and the social sciences. William Paterson's acceptance rate sits at approximately 94%, which is a benefit to those seeking to forge a better future and rise out of their circumstances. Ultimately, this university is one of the best places to get your life on track and take your education to the next level.

19. Fairleigh Dickinson University-Florham Campus

Score: 83.8

Average Net Price: $21,754

Retention Rate: 81%

Graduation Rate: 57%

Salary After Attending: $55,994

Fairleigh Dickinson University-Florham sits at #63 among Regional Universities North. The most popular majors include degrees such as liberal arts, business, and the humanities. Students also have the option of obtaining dual degrees, a process that involves working towards bachelor's and master's degrees simultaneously. The Florham Campus of Fairleigh Dickinson University emphasizes the importance of balancing education and extracurricular activities, such as intramural sports and clubs. All major choices allow students the freedom to participate fully in extracurricular activities and acquire one-of-a-kind skills that set them up for a lifetime of personal and professional accomplishment.

20. Caldwell University

Score: 83.5

Average Net Price: $20,175

Retention Rate: 81%

Graduation Rate: 55%

Salary After Attending: $51,823

Caldwell University is a private institution that has been serving members of its community and jumpstarting its students' futures since its founding in 1939. Today, the school ranks #93 among Regional Universities in North, and although tuition can average a relatively high amount, the school's high retention rate implies that attending students are more likely to remain here to pursue their education rather than transfer to a different university. The top three most popular majors pursued by Caldwell students are within the realms of health professions, business, and psychology. Caldwell also offers a few dual-degree opportunities and additional graduate programs to enable students to continue their educations further. Caldwell seniors' capstone projects categorically boast distinguished results while providing the students completing them with beneficial marketing opportunities and invaluable real-world experience.

21. Georgian Court University

Score: 83.3

Average Net Price: $20,312

Retention Rate: 79%

Graduation Rate: 64%

Salary After Attending: $46,953

Georgian Court University is a private institution that has been serving its suburban community and providing students with high-quality postsecondary education for over 100 years. With just under 80% of classes hosting fewer than 20 students, this school knows what it means to individualize education, enabling students to obtain the one-on-one instruction that they need to succeed. GCU ranks #101 among Regional Universities North. A couple of the most popular degree programs are psychology and registered nursing. Unlike most of the schools on this list, GCU does not offer virtual bachelor's degrees. So, if you are the type of student that works more efficiently on-campus, obtain your degree at Georgian Court University.

22. Rider University

Score: 83.3

Average Net Price: $27,882

Retention Rate: 78%

Graduation Rate: 67%

Salary After Attending: $56,442

Since it was established in 1865, Rider University has been committed to the advancement of postsecondary education and opening opportunities for its students. It ranks #22 among Regional Universities North, #82 among Top Performers on Socail Mobility, and #25 for Best Value Schools. Approximately 33% of students are pursuing business administration and management degrees, with education and visual and performing arts being the next two most popular choices.

Click Here for More Information

23. Centenary University

Score: 83.0

Average Net Price: $16,105

Retention Rate: 72%

Graduation Rate: 62%

Salary After Attending: $51,404

Private and founded on Christian principles, Centenary University can be found in Hackettstown, in the state of New Jersey. It is a relatively modest school, with only 1,032 students enrolled in the undergraduate program. The percentage of applicants who are accepted into Centenary University is 93%. Equine Studies, Business, and Criminal Justice and Safety Studies are three of the most common majors chosen by students. Alumni of Centenary University receive a median base salary of $37,900 after graduating from the university, where the graduation rate is 62%. A wide variety of undergraduate, graduate, and adult certificate programs are available at Centenary University, which serves as the primary academic and cultural asset for the region that includes northwest New Jersey.

24. New Jersey City University

Score: 82.5

Average Net Price: $13,297

Retention Rate: 76%

Graduation Rate: 54%

Salary After Attending: $46,606

New Jersey City University has been committed to enriching its community and bolstering its students' futures through education since it was founded in 1927. Today, tuition rates remain relatively low even for those paying out-of-state tuition; a fact made noteworthy due to its relevance to the school's placement at #59 among Top Performers on Social Mobility. A few of the most popular majors include registered nursing, psychology, and criminal justice. NJCU upholds an acceptance rate of 96% and is considered by many to be one of the least selective post-secondary educational institutions in the country. Ultimately, New Jersey City University is the perfect place for those willing to put in the work to overcome their situations and forge a bright future.

25. Kean University

Score: 81.5

Average Net Price: $18,191

Retention Rate: 74%

Graduation Rate: 59%

Salary After Attending: $50,888

Positioned a mere 30-minute drive from New York City and just 90 minutes away from Philadelphia, the campus boasts an abundance of possibilities for exploration, internships, and immersion in vibrant hubs of creativity. Kean students get to choose from almost 50 different undergraduate majors and more than 30 different master's degrees, as well as over 150 clubs. They can also write for the school newspaper, or even visit the nearby zoo, which hosts two of the school's cougar mascots. Many Kean students pursue the school's more popular degrees, which include psychology, biology, and business.

26. Rabbinical College of America

Score: 79.5

Average Net Price: $13,639

Retention Rate: 76%

Graduation Rate: 33%

Salary After Attending: $32,663

A private institution of higher learning, Rabbinical America can be found in Morris Township, New Jersey, in the Greater New York City Area. A total of 249 first-year students are enrolled at this comparatively small academic institution. The rate of individuals who are accepted into Rabbinical America is 84%. Talmudic and Rabbinical Studies is the only available major that can be chosen. Alumni of Rabbinical America, who account for 22% of the school's graduates, make a median starting salary of $17,400 after graduation. The Rabbinical College of America is a school that puts theory into practice. Our students receive an education that prepares them to be of service to humanity by addressing unfulfilled needs whenever and wherever they may emerge.

27. Eastern International College-Jersey City (Main Campus)

Score: 78.8

Average Net Price: $20,129

Retention Rate: 73%

Graduation Rate: 63%

Salary After Attending: $29,574

A private college run for profit, Eastern International - Jersey City can be found in Jersey City, New Jersey, in the greater New York City metropolitan area. It is a relatively small school, with only 173 students enrolled in the undergraduate program. There is a one hundred percent acceptance rate at Eastern International in Jersey City. The fields of Nursing, Dental Hygiene, and Sonography and Ultrasound Technology are among the most popular majors. Alumni of Eastern International - Jersey City, who graduate at a rate of 67% of students, report a typical starting salary of $20,900 after graduation.

28. Saint Elizabeth University

Score: 78.0

Average Net Price: $20,344

Retention Rate: 73%

Graduation Rate: 57%

Salary After Attending: $45,131

The College of Saint Elizabeth is a Catholic liberal arts school that has been devoted to administering faith-based education and uplifting its community since its founding in 1899. Presently, the institution presents an extensive array of undergraduate and graduate programs, fostering an enriching academic environment. Within these realms, students are encouraged to actively interact with their fellow peers, colleagues, and esteemed professors while embarking on diverse majors such as biology, art, dance, music, health administration, social work, and numerous other disciplines. Within the fully-comprehensive curriculum students acquire real-world experience, obtain crucial life lessons, and establish strong mentorships with trusted advisors and instructors.

29. Berkeley College- Woodland Park

Score: 77.5

Average Net Price: $14,923

Retention Rate: 62%

Graduation Rate: 42%

Salary After Attending: $40,213

Berkeley College at Woodland Park is a private institution of higher education that is found in Woodland Park, New Jersey, in the Greater New York City Area. It is a comparatively small educational establishment with a total of 2,105 undergraduate students enrolled. The Berkeley - Woodland Park admissions rate is a perfect 100 percent. Many students choose to major in business, police and criminal science, or medical assistant studies. U.S. News and World Report ranked Berkeley College #86 in Top Performers on Social Mobility. Alumni of the Berkeley - Woodland Park campus, of which 48% of students graduate, typically begin their careers with an annual income of $30,000.

30. Eastern International College-Belleville

Score: 77.3

Average Net Price: $23,133

Retention Rate: 75%

Graduation Rate: 63%

Salary After Attending: $29,574

A private college operated for profit, Eastern International - Belleville may be found in Belleville Township, New Jersey, inside the metropolitan area of New York City. It is a rather small educational establishment, with only 152 first-year students enrolled there. The acceptance rate at Eastern International - Belleville is a hundred percent. Founded on a commitment to its students' personal and professional growth, Eastern International College is an inclusive and career-focused institution of higher learning. With creative lesson plans, cutting-edge tools, opportunities for "hands-on" experience, and supportive student services. The fields of nursing, sonography and ultrasound technology, and cardiovascular technology are consistently ranked among the most sought-after academic disciplines. Alumni of Eastern International - Belleville, who graduate at a rate of 79% of students, report an average beginning salary of $20,900 after graduation.

31. Bloomfield College

Score: 75.5

Average Net Price: $19,236

Retention Rate: 64%

Graduation Rate: 33%

Salary After Attending: $44,790

Today, it ranks at #108 among Top Performers on Social Mobility and currently offers more than 40 different programs as well as various career development programs to aid in a student's post-college success. According to the school's official website, it ranks at #20 among colleges that improve economic standing and is considered a "workforce ready" institution. In other words, every Bloomfield student can be sure to receive opportunities for high-quality internships and job placement.

32. Pillar College

Score: 75.0

Average Net Price: $18,737

Retention Rate: 68%

Graduation Rate: 34%

Salary After Attending: $30,497

The Newark, New Jersey campus of Pillar College is a small, private, Christian university serving the greater New York City area. There are just 262 undergraduates at this school, making it rather tiny. There is no rejection at Pillar University, as they keep a 100% acceptance rate. Majors in psychology, liberal arts and humanities, and business are consistently among the most popular choices among college freshmen. Pillar College is New Jersey's sole evangelical Christian college. We offer standard Associate's, Bachelor's, and Master's degrees as well as enhanced and alternative academic programs for adult learners.

33. Eastwick College-Hackensack

Score: 74.5

Average Net Price: $24,791

Retention Rate: 60%

Graduation Rate: 60%

Salary After Attending: $41,031

Located in the New York metropolitan area, Eastwick College - Hackensack is a private, for-profit institution of higher education. Only 438 undergraduates are enrolled at this school, making it quite modest. Admission at Eastwick College - Hackensack is guaranteed to all who apply. Only 42% of Eastwick College - Hackensack's students graduate, but those who do have an average beginning salary of $30,700. Programs at Eastwick College - Hackensack emphasize experiential learning by having students deal with real patients or simulate real-world scenarios using equipment and techniques used by local businesses. Therefore, they can be sure that all grads are equipped with the self-assurance and practical knowledge necessary to find and keep rewarding employment.

34. Devry University-New Jersey

Score: 72.8

Average Net Price: $21,220

Retention Rate: 53%

Graduation Rate: 23%

Salary After Attending: $44,484

Iselin, New Jersey is home to DeVry University - New Jersey, a private university that operates for profit and is located in the New York metropolitan area. There are 96 undergraduates enrolled at this rather modest educational establishment. The admittance percentage at DeVry University in New Jersey is 33%, meaning getting in will be fairly difficult. The fields of business, computer systems networking and telecommunications, and computer systems analysis are among the most popular majors. Alumni of DeVry University - New Jersey, of which 37% of students graduate, earn an average beginning income of $32,600 upon entering the workforce.

College facts have been collected from the U.S. News and World Report's Education Panel found here.

#rider

Related Programs That Might Interest You

Learn about start dates, transferring credits, availability of financial aid, and more by contacting the universities below.
